1.text: Man, born of woman! Of few days, and full of trouble!

2.text: As a flower he hath gone forth, and is cut off, And he fleeth as a shadow and standeth not.

3.text: Also—on this Thou hast opened Thine eyes, And dost bring me into judgment with Thee.

4.text: Who giveth a clean thing out of an unclean? not one.

5.text: If determined are his days, The number of his months are with Thee, His limit Thou hast made, And he passeth not over;

6.text: Look away from off him that he may cease, Till he enjoy as an hireling his day.

7.text: For there is of a tree hope, if it be cut down, That again it doth change, That its tender branch doth not cease.

8.text: If its root becometh old in the earth, And its stem doth die in the dust,

9.text: From the fragrance of water it doth flourish, And hath made a crop as a plant.

10.text: And a man dieth, and becometh weak, And man expireth, and where is he?

11.text: Waters have gone away from a sea, And a river becometh waste and dry.

12.text: And man hath lain down, and riseth not, Till the wearing out of the heavens they awake not, Nor are roused from their sleep.

13.text: O that in Sheol Thou wouldest conceal me, Hide me till the turning of Thine anger, Set for me a limit, and remember me.

14.text: If a man dieth—doth he revive? All days of my warfare I wait, till my change come.

15.text: Thou dost call, and I—I answer Thee; To the work of Thy hands Thou hast desire.

16.text: But now, my steps Thou numberest, Thou dost not watch over my sin.

17.text: Sealed up in a bag is my transgression, And Thou sewest up mine iniquity.

18.text: And yet, a falling mountain wasteth away, And a rock is removed from its place.

19.text: Stones have waters worn away, Their outpourings wash away the dust of earth, And the hope of man Thou hast destroyed.

20.text: Thou prevailest over him for ever, and he goeth, He is changing his countenance, And Thou sendest him away.

21.text: Honoured are his sons, and he knoweth not; And they are little, and he attendeth not to them.

22.text: Only—his flesh for him is pained, And his soul for him doth mourn.’
